results.title: Janus. Eps 11 and 12: Without prejudice. Improper influences
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 11 and 12 of the television series Janus. “Without prejudice” (50 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) gives an insight to jury selection procedures and the workings of a jury during a trial. Steve Hennessey (Leon Teague) and Darren Mack (Nique Needles) are finally being tried for “trafficking of drugs of dependence” with Dale Cassidy (previously a Prosecution witness at the commital hearing) now appearing as the main witness for the Prosecution. Peter Faithful and Rob Griffin are slowly mounting evidence against Mal Hennessey for the murder of Patrick Clancy. “Improper influences” (48 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). Judge Grossman (Denis Moore) is determined to see the Steve Hennessey drug trial through, despite growing concern about his health. Defence’s case focuses on the questionable quality of the police surveillance video-tape of the drug deal. Peter Faithful’s unrelenting pursuit of evidence to get Mal Hennessey for murder leads him to Mal’s ex-girlfriend who is serving time in Fairlea Women’s Prison. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Grant Piro, Sheryl Munks, Damian Foley, Greg Fleet and Pepe Trevor.

results.title: Janus. Eps 17 and 18: Right to remain silent. My learned friend, Mr Hennessey
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 17 and 18 of the television series Janus. “Right to remain silent” (51 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith). The internal investigation into the shooting of Steve Hennessey continues. Meantime, Roz Breen (Jeanette Cronin) who has been charged with smuggling drugs into prison, decides to fight the case. Her defence is “duress”, caused by intimidation and fear of the Hennessey family. Although Steve is dead, the drug trafficking connection still lives on. “My learned friend, Mr Hennessey” (52 mins) (directed by Michael Carson) shows Mal Hennessey (Brett Swain) in a somewhat different light to the usual cold, indifferent violent person that he can be, as he defends himself in a commital hearing on a charge of “Breach of prison” relating to his escape from the Police Van. With Shirl Hennessey still in Fairlea and no money to pay Michael Kidd to defend him, Mal has to take on the system. And take on the system he does, much to Vic Manoulis’s frustration and Peter Faithful’s growing concern. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Leverne McDonnell, Simon Chilvers, Paul Gleeson.

results.title: Janus. Eps 19 and 20: Confess and avoid. A Prima facie case
results.creator_credit: Robert Klenner, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 19 and 20 of the television series Janus. “Confess and avoid” (48 mins) (directed by Robert Klenner) literally means confess to the lesser charges and hopefully avoid the serious charge. Michael Kidd has not lost a case in eight years but doubts start to set in when he finds himself defending a young law student, Ian Bisley (Richard Sutherland) who has been charged with culpable driving. Jenny Hanson (Jane Menelaus) as representative for the Crown Prosecution at the same time, is not looking forward to doing battle with the formidable Michael Kidd. “A Prima facie case” (48 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). Witnesses are called to give evidence at the commital hearing into Steve Hennessey’s death. Allegations are being made that Peter Faithful covered up for his mates and conflicting versions by the witnesses as to whether Steve Hennessey was armed, only complicates matters further. Peter Faithful decides to confront Michael Kidd’s allegations of persecution and corruption by taking the witness stand. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Felix Nobis, Tamsin West, David Bradshaw and Steve Vidler.

results.title: Janus. Eps 25 and 26: Mute by visitation. Elements of murder
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 25 and 26 of the television series Janus. “Mute by visitation” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith). Glenda de Bono is listed to preside as Judge on a retrial of a rape case. This is her first major trial since becoming a County Judge. The unusual aspect of this trial however, is that both the victim, Colleen Maitland (Danni Wright) and the alleged rapist, Tim Lester (Mike Canfield) are profoundly deaf - so are their families and the witnesses. Meanwhile, application for Mal Hennessey’s blood sample for DNA testing is granted and Peter Faithful gets a bonus when “Gazza”, during his interview, puts Shirl Hennessey in the picture as the one to organise the disposal of Patrick Clancy’s body. “Elements of murder” (51 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) is the final episode of Janus. Mal Hennessey and Shirl Hennessey face a commital hearing - Mal for murder and Shirl for accessory after the fact to murder. The use of DNA as corroborating material, and Sandy (Mal’s ex girlfriend), Gazza and Tomlinson as witnesses for the Prosecution, make it almost impossible for Michael Kidd to get Mal and Shirl off. And the internal investigation into Steve Hennessey’s death is closing in on Peter Faithful and his team. A dramatic conclusion to this brilliant Australian television series. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Louise Siversen, Brett Swain, Paulene Terry-Beitz, Leverne McDonnell, Belinda McClory and Victoria Eagger.

results.title: The West
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ives, Michael Kantor, Jody Abramson, Time-Life Video & Television, Florentine Films, WETA-TV and Insignia Films
results.brief_description: A historical account through to 1914 of the American West presented as an eight-part documentary series for television. Includes archival footage, stills, newsreels, diaries and artefacts, and commentary by historians, writers and anthropologists (American and Native American), with spectacular images of the landscape and haunting background music. Narrated by Peter Coyote.

Narrated by Peter Coyote.

results.title: The West. Eps 1 and 2: The People. Empire upon the trails
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ives, Michael Kantor, Jody Abramson, Time-Life Video & Television, Florentine Films, WETA-TV and Insignia Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The West”.
Episode one (to 1806): “The People” (88 mins) Begins the historical mapping of a vast expanse of land (over 2 million square miles) which stretches from the Mississippi to the Pacific Ocean, from the northern plains to the Rio Grande and which for a thousand generations belonged to more than 3 million Indians of various nations including the Comanches, the Hidatsas, the Cheyenne, the Apache, the Zunis, and the Hopi. Describes the lives and cultures of some of the tribes, their rituals, sacred sites, beliefs and customs. The first Europeans to set foot in the West was in 1528 by a small group of shipwrecked Spanish soldiers lead by Alvar Nunez Cabeza de Vaca. This episode tells of the Spanish invasion and conquest, their religious fervour and hunger for land and the devastation which their wars, famine and diseases brought upon the native Indian. Follows through to October 1804 when American explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark set off on an expedition to explore the Missouri River and hopefully find a north-west passage across to the Pacific Ocean. Episode two (1806-1848): “Empire upon the trails” (84 mins) Deals with the control and destiny of the West. By 1821, two Republics had claimed a sizeable part of the West - the United States (half of the West) and the Republic of Mexico (South-west and California). England still had outposts in the Pacific North-west and several Indian nations held fast to their lands. Covers the Battle of the Alamo, the arrival of the Mormons, the formation of the States of Texas and California and the addition of Oregon, Washington and Idaho to the Union, the Mexican-American War and the relocation of some 90,000 Indians. In 1848 gold was discovered - “Nothing in the West would ever be the same again”. Narrated by Peter Coyote.
results.title_for_label: The West. Eps 1 and 2: The People. Empire upon the trails
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Ives, Michael Kantor, Jody Abramson, Time-Life Video & Television, Florentine Films, WETA-TV and Insignia Films

results.title: The West. Eps 7 and 8: The Geography of hope. One sky above us
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ives, Michael Kantor, Jody Abramson, Time-Life Video & Television, Florentine Films, WETA-TV and Insignia Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The West”.
Episode seven (1877-1887): “The Geography of hope” (85 mins) - By 1877, American conquest of the West was almost complete leaving the Chinese, Mexican-Americans and the Indians no longer welcome - either assimilate or get out. Discrimination also extended to the African-Americans once the Federal Troops withdrew from the South. The grassy plains became desirable for farming and grazing, railroads were being established, and small settlements and farming communities were expanding and developing into large cities and states. In the meantime, the Indian people were being forced off their land and into reservations. Harsh restrictions were put on the Indians and by law they were compelled to change their identity, to assimilate, speak English, attend American schools (military style) and were banned from practising any of their ceremonies and rites. Children as young as five were taken away from their parents, often never to be seen again. Episode eight (1887-1914): “One sky above us” (111 mins) - The final episode of this magnificent series. Covers the 1887 Dawes Act which resulted in the breaking up of Indian tribes and their ownership to land; the shooting of Chief Sitting Bull and the slaughter of Lakota Indians at Wounded Knee in 1890; mining corporations, industrialization and ecological destruction during the mid 1880’s; harnessing of the Owens River resulting in the Los Angeles Reservoir in 1913. Throughout this series we have followed the tragic history of the Indians, and in particular, the man of peace, Chief Joseph of the Nez Perce tribe. In Chief Joseph’s words “Whenever the white man treats the Indian as they treat each other, then we will have no more wars. We shall all be alike — brothers of one father, and one mother, with one sky above us and one country around us, and one government for all. Then the Great Spirit who rules above will smile upon this land, and all people may be one people”. Narrated by Peter Coyote.
results.title_for_label: The West. Eps 7 and 8: The Geography of hope. One sky above us
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Ives, Michael Kantor, Jody Abramson, Time-Life Video & Television, Florentine Films, WETA-TV and Insignia Films

results.title: The West. Eps 3 and 4: The Speck of the future. Death runs riot
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ives, Michael Kantor, Jody Abramson, Time-Life Video & Television, Florentine Films, WETA-TV and Insignia Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The West”.
Episode three (1848-1856): “The Speck of the future” (85 mins) - The discovery of gold in California in 1848 changed the West forever. Gold diggers from all over the world came to seek their fortune. The gold rush also brought thousands of American immigrants travelling in wagon trains and by boat. Wherever gold was discovered, the pattern set in California repeated itself - Americans rushed in, towns sprang up, and Indian tribes found themselves outnumbered in their own lands. This episode talks about the “Forty-niners”; Kit Carson; the Fort Laramie Treaty of 1851; the devastating effect of the invasion of foreigners to the Native Indian tribes - the slaughter, the famine and the diseases; San Francisco (the West’s first full-fledged city), and Levi Strauss. Episode four (1856-1868): “Death runs riot” (85 mins) - A myth had grown up about the West: “you could escape and be free”. The Americans began moving West in increasing numbers, staking claims on Indian land, clearing the land, building towns and cities. But with it came slavery, the American nation’s most divisive issue, bringing war and bloodshed and eventually the Civil War. Mexican-Americans also suffered persecution and removal by murder or otherwise at the hands of the Texas Rangers. The Cheyenne Peace Chiefs led by “Black Kettle” faced a losing battle with the whites and war and revenge would rage for many years. Narrated by Peter Coyote.

results.title: Robert Rauschenberg: man at work
results.creator_credit: Chris Granlund, Guggenheim Productions, RM Arts and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Robert Rauschenberg, one of the most important artists of the twentieth century. life works and practice are featured in this documentary. Influenced mostly by popular culture and the everyday his practice has continued for over 40 years being one of the most influential artists of his time. His retrospective at the Guggenheim, New York in 1997 is featured as well as his 1/4 Mile or 2 Furlong Piece, a multipanelled autobiographical piece begun in 1982 that is expected to out measure the length of its title once completed. Living and working since the 70’s in his Captiva island studio off Florida, Rauschenberg constructs 1/4 Mile, demonstrating his process whilst giving us an opportunity to see the piece for the first time in its entirety. Narrated by Sean Barrett.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Granlund, Guggenheim Productions, RM Arts and BBC

Robert Rauschenberg, one of the most important artists of the twentieth century. life works and practice are featured in this documentary. Influenced mostly by popular culture and the everyday his practice has continued for over 40 years being one of the most influential artists of his time. His retrospective at the Guggenheim, New York in 1997 is featured as well as his 1/4 Mile or 2 Furlong Piece, a multipanelled autobiographical piece begun in 1982 that is expected to out measure the length of its title once completed. Living and working since the 70’s in his Captiva island studio off Florida, Rauschenberg constructs 1/4 Mile, demonstrating his process whilst giving us an opportunity to see the piece for the first time in its entirety. Narrated by Sean Barrett.
